concept.title: Example: Constrain a domain module using RNG
concept.shortdesc: In this scenario, a DITA architect wants to use only a subset of the elements defined in the highlighting domain. They want to use b and i but not line-through, overline, sup, sup, tt, or u. Their implementation uses RNG for its grammar files.

keywords.indexterm: constraintsexamplesrestricting content model for a domain
examplesconstraintsrestricting content model for a domain

conbody.p: When using RNG, domains can be constrained directly in the document-type shells.

li.p: They open the document-type shell for topic in an XML editor, and then they modify the "MODULE INCLUSIONS" division to exclude the elements that they do not want the implementation to use:
li.codeblock: MODULE INCLUSIONS ... ..
li.note: The DITA architect made a choice as to where in the document-type shell they would implement the constraint. It can be placed either in the "Element-type configuration integration" or the "Module inclusions" section.

ol.li: They make similar changes to all the other document-type shells in which they want to constrain the highlighting domain.
